Pre-Game Insights: The Red Sox have turned to Rich Hill to bolster their pitching for the stretch run.
Hill will become the only current player to appear in at least one game in each of the last 20 seasons (starting in 2005).
The Red Sox have backed themselves into a corner with tough losses and sloppy play of late, but like so many times this season, they turned a corner on Tuesday.
Post-Match Reflections: Manager Alex Cora reflected on how optimistic he felt with the additions at the deadline compared to where the club is now in a stretch of 27 games in 27 days.
Cora suggested he might keep the same schedule for Wednesday after a hard-fought win on Tuesday.
Cora had his club report to the ballpark a few hours later than usual on Tuesday to give them a breather.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Hill decided to take most of the 2024 season away from baseball in order to coach his 12-year-old son Brice’s Little League team.

Hill worked out at Champion Physical Therapy Performance in Waltham throughout the summer, and in early August, he took a trip to the Cape Cod Baseball League to face hitters in Falmouth to see how his pitches played while using their Trackman system.
The Red Sox have several journeymen on their roster, along with veterans like Chris Martin and Kenley Jansen.
Others: Hill signed a minor-league deal last week, but was deemed ready after pitching two innings for Triple-A Worcester on Friday.
The Red Sox have lost several pitchers to injuries, including Lucas Sims and Luis García, who were acquired at the trade deadline.
